title: Trouble looms for Mitch McConnell's Senate
content:
A summer of gridlock is bearing down on Washington , threatening to put an end to the burst of legislative productivity that kicked off Mitch McConnell ’ s reign atop the Senate .
Minority Leader Harry Reid foreshadowed the shift recently with vows to essentially shut down the appropriations process and block highway and defense bills unless Republicans move markedly to the left . With deadlines looming on several must-pass bills , the stage is set for brinkmanship that could last through the summer and into the thick of the 2016 presidential primary season .
Democrats believe they have the upper hand after Republicans allowed government surveillance authorities to temporarily expire last week , stoking criticism of McConnell ’ s stewardship of the Senate . The mood in the chamber has turned more antagonistic over the past week , as Reid and McConnell have mixed it up on the Senate floor over who controls the agenda and which party is being more obstructionist .
During a heated debate on the PATRIOT Act last week , McConnell turned to Reid ( D-Nev. ) to pointedly warn him that “ you don ’ t get to set the schedule anymore. ” And after Reid threatened to hold up spending , defense and highway bills , McConnell told radio host Hugh Hewitt that Republicans will probably confirm only a trickle of President Barack Obama ’ s lifetime judicial appointments during the rest of his presidency .
“ Under his leadership , the Senate will shirk its constitutional duties by not confirming judges , ” Reid fumed on the Senate floor . “ What a bad standard to set . ”
While Republicans have confirmed only four federal judges and stumbled by allowing surveillance laws to briefly lapse , the majority leader has presided over a legislative bonanza — by recent standards — during his first five months as majority leader . The Senate has passed fast-track trade legislation , installed an oversight law for a nuclear deal with Iran and finalized a budget with the House .
The previous Congress , by contrast , was marked by constant stalemate and was one of the least productive in recent decades : It is best known for being the first since the mid-1990s to shut down the government . The Senate ’ s signature legislative accomplishment was a comprehensive immigration reform bill that died in the House . Faced with myriad GOP filibusters — including to appropriations bills — Reid prioritized nominations over seeking bipartisan consensus with Republicans who he said would never come to the table .
Now , the big-ticket accomplishments of 2015 may soon give way to a similar paralysis , as Congress cruises into a series of fights in which congressional Democrats ’ leverage lies mainly in their power to filibuster . Reid has called a national defense authorization bill that Republicans are pushing a “ waste of time ” because the White House has promised to veto it and pledged to block Republican spending bills and an extension of highway funding unless Republicans agree to fund Democratic spending programs and provide long-term certainty in the transportation budget .
“ They ’ re threatening all sorts of stuff , ” said an unimpressed Senate Majority Whip John Cornyn ( R-Texas ) .
McConnell , in turn , is angling to outmaneuver Democrats by pledging on Monday to first move a defense policy bill and then immediately follow it with a defense spending bill — practically daring Democrats to follow through on their threat to filibuster measures seen as critical to national security . Already McConnell and House Speaker John Boehner ( R-Ohio ) have gotten mileage out of Reid ’ s “ waste of time ” remark .
“ If you look at the shape the world ’ s in , ” McConnell ( R-Ky. ) said on Louisville radio on Monday , “ my view is the nation ’ s defense right now cries out for priority . ”
Beyond the latest clash between the partisan rivals , the coming months will be driven by a sequence of deadlines that lawmakers have shown little inclination or ability to get in front of . The Export-Import Bank charter expires at the end of the month , and after that Republicans will have to zero in on avoiding a shutdown of federal highway construction after July 31 . Then two months after that they ’ ll have to figure out how to keep the federal government open , since spending bills that would do the job are expected to go nowhere .
Those deadlines will consume much of Congress ’ energy and are the focal point of both Democrats ’ messaging strategy and McConnell ’ s hopes of setting the stage for a Republican president .
The task facing Republicans is daunting . They are already scrambling to find billions needed to keep building roads and bridges during the peak summer construction season . McConnell set out to make the Senate function normally again by passing 12 individual bills to fund the federal government instead of allowing a constant cycle of fiscal cliffs . But Reid ’ s intention to blockade GOP spending bills may well upend the majority leader ’ s plans .
Harry Reid and Mitch McConnell have argued recently on the Senate floor over who controls the agenda and which party is being more obstructionist . | AP Photo
“ The one thing that Mitch doesn ’ t have is time , ” said one Republican senator . “ In a perfect world , he ’ d want to do all [ the ] appropriations bills . But obviously that ’ s not going to happen because we don ’ t have the time . ”
The political consequences could be steep if Democrats follow through on their filibuster threats and government shutdown clocks return to the cable networks . But the stakes are also high for the Republican majorities in the House and Senate , which want to convince Americans that keeping them in charge and electing a GOP president is the key to unlocking D.C. gridlock .
The Ex-Im Bank and transportation bills present the most immediate tests — and the politics are complicated .
McConnell personally opposes renewing the bank charter , even though Democrats and many Republicans disagree . The majority leader , however , has said he ’ ll allow at least a vote on the Senate floor . That could set up a scenario in which Democrats go along with a temporary transportation bill — despite Reid ’ s insistence on a longer-term highway funding measure — in exchange for the GOP ’ s help in renewing the bank , which helps arrange credit for U.S. exporters .
The problem , though , is that the Ex-Im charter expires at the end of June , while highway funding doesn ’ t dry up until a month after that .
Reid says McConnell would be making a mistake to pair the Ex-Im and highway debates : By that point , the bank will have lapsed , the Democratic leader said .
“ If we wait until then , Ex-Im will be expired , ” Reid said in an interview late last week . “ I don ’ t think that ’ s very good legislating . ”
Despite the tough talk of late , no one on Capitol Hill is speaking yet about a government shutdown come Sept. 30 , the end of the fiscal year . Even if Democrats block spending bills and stymie the GOP ’ s hopes of reviving the appropriations process , the parties could compromise on a broad spending bill or agree to an emergency extension of current funding levels , a so-called continuing resolution that the GOP has been hoping to avoid .
While McConnell is trying to keep in check expectations of what he can accomplish in a divided body , he does decide when legislation — and nominees — come to the Senate floor . He leveraged that power to great effect in March by linking Attorney General Loretta Lynch ’ s confirmation to a human trafficking bill .
McConnell made clear again on Monday that setting the agenda remains the most powerful tool he possesses in a Senate where it ’ s a lot easier to kill legislation than it is to pass it .
“ The big advantage to being in the majority is you get to determine what the schedule is … it doesn ’ t guarantee the outcome , ” McConnell said on Louisville radio . “ There ’ s not much we can do with the simple Republican majority , but we do determine the order of things . ”
